Substrand: Places and our connections to them
ContentDescription: The places in which they live, why their places are important to them, the features of places, and how places can be looked after
Elaboration: Identifying the place they live in and belong to, such as a neighbourhood, suburb, town, rural locality or an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander People’s Country and Place

Substrand: Places and our connections to them
ContentDescription: The places in which they live, why their places are important to them, the features of places, and how places can be looked after
Elaboration: Discussing how places support people’s lives, with housing, water, shops, schools, recreation and other services and facilities, and understanding that their closest relationships are with people in or near their place

Substrand: Places and our connections to them
ContentDescription: The places in which they live, why their places are important to them, the features of places, and how places can be looked after
Elaboration: Exploring why people have attachment to places, such as through reading and viewing poems, songs, paintings and stories about people’s feelings about their place

Substrand: Places and our connections to them
ContentDescription: The places in which they live, why their places are important to them, the features of places, and how places can be looked after
Elaboration: Identifying some significant features of their place, such as a river, hill, shopping centre, park, school or religious building

Substrand: Places and our connections to them
ContentDescription: The places in which they live, why their places are important to them, the features of places, and how places can be looked after
Elaboration: Identifying places they consider to be ‘special’, such as their bedroom, a play area, a holiday location or a place of family significance

Substrand: Places and our connections to them
ContentDescription: The places in which they live, why their places are important to them, the features of places, and how places can be looked after
Elaboration: Writing or drawing about their feelings about their place and explaining why the place is special to them

Substrand: Places and our connections to them
ContentDescription: The places in which they live, why their places are important to them, the features of places, and how places can be looked after
Elaboration: Discussing why it is important to care for the places people live in and how places can be looked after

Substrand: Places and our connections to them
ContentDescription: The places in which they live, why their places are important to them, the features of places, and how places can be looked after
Elaboration: Making a pictorial map of the location of the people who are most important in their lives and describing any patterns they observe

Substrand: Places and our connections to them
ContentDescription: How places are identified and named, including by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples
Elaboration: Examining the names of places in the local area and their meanings

Substrand: Places and our connections to them
ContentDescription: How places are identified and named, including by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples
Elaboration: Investigating the names and meanings given to local features and places by local Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander Peoples

Substrand: Places and our connections to them
ContentDescription: How places are identified and named, including by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples
Elaboration: Discussing the differences between European and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander placenames

Substrand: Places and our connections to them
ContentDescription: How places are identified and named, including by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples
Elaboration: Identifying the Country and Place in which their school is located and using the name of the local Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander People’s language group

Substrand: Places and our connections to them
ContentDescription: The interconnections between Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples and Country and Place, and the importance of Country and Place
Elaboration: Discussing why the words Country and Place are used by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples for the places to which they belong

Substrand: Places and our connections to them
ContentDescription: The interconnections between Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples and Country and Place, and the importance of Country and Place
Elaboration: Recognising that some Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples have special connections to many Countries and Places through marriage, birth, parents, residence and chosen or forced movement, and that they can identify with more than one Country

Substrand: Places and our connections to them
ContentDescription: The interconnections between Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples and Country and Place, and the importance of Country and Place
Elaboration: Describing the connections that local Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples have with the land, sea, sky and animals of their Country and Place

Substrand: Places and our connections to them
ContentDescription: The interconnections between Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples and Country and Place, and the importance of Country and Place
Elaboration: Inviting members of the Traditional Owner group to talk about their Country and Place and places of cultural and historical significance to their community, and discussing why and when Acknowledgement of Country and Welcome to Country are used at ceremonies and events

Substrand: Places and our connections to them
ContentDescription: How places can be spatially represented from local to national scales, the representation of Australia as states and territories and Countries and Places, and Australia’s major features and places
Elaboration: Understanding that a place is an area of space that has been identified, named and given meaning by people

Substrand: Places and our connections to them
ContentDescription: How places can be spatially represented from local to national scales, the representation of Australia as states and territories and Countries and Places, and Australia’s major features and places
Elaboration: Using their home address to describe the scale of places, from the personal scale of their home to the local scale of their suburb or town, the regional scale of their state, and the national scale of their country, and identifying each scale on a map

Substrand: Places and our connections to them
ContentDescription: How places can be spatially represented from local to national scales, the representation of Australia as states and territories and Countries and Places, and Australia’s major features and places
Elaboration: Using a map to locate and name the states and territories in Australia, along with their capital cities, and using the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies (AIATSIS) Map of Indigenous Australia to identify Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Countries and Places

Substrand: Places and our connections to them
ContentDescription: How places can be spatially represented from local to national scales, the representation of Australia as states and territories and Countries and Places, and Australia’s major features and places
Elaboration: Using European and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander names, where available, to identify the major natural features of Australia, such as rivers, deserts, the Great Dividing Range, the Great Barrier Reef, Uluru and Kati Thanda, and locating them with annotations on a map

Substrand: Places and our connections to them
ContentDescription: The natural and constructed features of places, how they change and how they can be cared for
Elaboration: Using observations of the local place to identify and describe its features, such as hills, rivers, parks, forests and buildings, and locating them on a map

Substrand: Places and our connections to them
ContentDescription: The natural and constructed features of places, how they change and how they can be cared for
Elaboration: Listening to and viewing Aboriginal Dreaming and Creation stories of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples that identify the natural features and landmarks of a place, and traditional, sacred and significant sites

Substrand: Places and our connections to them
ContentDescription: The natural and constructed features of places, how they change and how they can be cared for
Elaboration: Using observations and/or photographs to identify changes in the natural and constructed features in their place, such as vegetation clearance, new buildings, new or upgraded roads, recent erosion, tree planting or crops

Substrand: Places and our connections to them
ContentDescription: The natural and constructed features of places, how they change and how they can be cared for
Elaboration: Describing local features people look after, such as bushland, wetlands, a park or a heritage building, and finding out why and how these features need to be cared for and who provides this care

Substrand: Places and our connections to them
ContentDescription: Weather and seasons, including Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples’ seasonal calendars
Elaboration: Describing the daily and seasonal weather of their place by its rainfall, temperature, sunshine and wind and comparing it with the weather of other places that they know or are aware of

Substrand: Places and our connections to them
ContentDescription: Weather and seasons, including Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples’ seasonal calendars
Elaboration: Comparing the European seasonal calendar with the Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander People’s seasonal calendar for their location

Substrand: Places and our connections to them
ContentDescription: People’s interconnections with places in Australia and the world
Elaboration: Examining the ways in which they are connected to other places through friends, relatives, family origin, religion, holidays, sport and things that people buy or obtain

Substrand: Places and our connections to them
ContentDescription: People’s interconnections with places in Australia and the world
Elaboration: Discussing how their place may be connected to events that have happened in other places, such as the Olympic Games or a major earthquake

ContentDescription: Ask geographical questions about places and our connection to them
Elaboration: Posing questions about the features of places and how students can look after them, after being encouraged to observe them using various senses

ContentDescription: Ask geographical questions about places and our connection to them
Elaboration: Posing questions with the stems ‘where’, ‘what’, ‘how’ and ‘why’ about places when provided with everyday objects and other sources, such as photos, maps and observation sketches

ContentDescription: Ask geographical questions about places and our connection to them
Elaboration: Asking questions before, during and after listening to stories about places

ContentDescription: Ask geographical questions about places and our connection to them
Elaboration: Developing inquiry questions about places, for example ‘What are the features of the place?’, ‘How far away is it?’, ‘How easy is it to get to?’, ‘How am I connected to it?’ and ‘How is it connected to other places?’

ContentDescription: Ask geographical questions about places and our connection to them
Elaboration: Developing questions about who looks after local features and how, what they like and do not like about their place, and why their place is important to them

ContentDescription: Ask geographical questions about places and our connection to them
Elaboration: Developing questions about the names given to local features and places by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples

ContentDescription: Collect, sort and record information and data from observations, including from fieldwork and maps
Elaboration: Collecting data and information by making observations outside the classroom, by interviewing people or from sources such as photographs, plans, satellite images, books and films

ContentDescription: Collect, sort and record information and data from observations, including from fieldwork and maps
Elaboration: Gathering evidence of features in a local place (e.g. using observations, online aerial photographs and sketches) and noting how they change (e.g. by comparing current observations of a place with photographs of it taken in the past, or recording observations of weather and seasons)

ContentDescription: Collect, sort and record information and data from observations, including from fieldwork and maps
Elaboration: Locating the places to which they are connected, such as through family, travel or friends, or the places they visit, such as for shopping, recreation, travel to school or other reasons, on a print, electronic, outline or wall map

ContentDescription: Collect, sort and record information and data from observations, including from fieldwork and maps
Elaboration: Interviewing older relatives or significant Elders about their feelings towards their place

ContentDescription: Collect, sort and record information and data from observations, including from fieldwork and maps
Elaboration: Collecting pictures of places they know or are aware of and annotating them to record or show information about the weather

ContentDescription: Collect, sort and record information and data from observations, including from fieldwork and maps
Elaboration: Identifying a place in their local area that they like, mapping the location and discussing why they like it and how they could care for it

ContentDescription: Represent and describe the information and data from observations in different formats, including sketches and labelled maps or photographs
Elaboration: Identifying features on a provided pictorial map or oblique aerial photograph of a familiar place and linking the representation of specific features to pictures they have drawn of those features; for example, using a pictorial map of a visited site such as a public garden or an oblique aerial photograph of their school to find familiar features, and then linking drawings of those features with lines to the features in the map or aerial photograph

ContentDescription: Represent and describe the information and data from observations in different formats, including sketches and labelled maps or photographs
Elaboration: Interpreting symbols and codes that provide information, such as map legends

ContentDescription: Represent and describe the information and data from observations in different formats, including sketches and labelled maps or photographs
Elaboration: Gathering evidence of features in a local place (e.g. using observations, online aerial photographs and sketches) and noting how they change (e.g. by comparing current observations of a place with photographs of it taken in the past, or recording observations of weather and seasons)

ContentDescription: Represent and describe the information and data from observations in different formats, including sketches and labelled maps or photographs
Elaboration: Recording data about the locations of places and their features on maps and/or plans; for example, labelling the location of their home on a map of the local area, or using a provided plan of their classroom and labelling its activity spaces, incorporating symbols to show locations of objects, places or significant features

ContentDescription: Represent and describe the information and data from observations in different formats, including sketches and labelled maps or photographs
Elaboration: Developing a pictorial table to categorise information; for example, matching clothes with seasons, activities with the weather and features with places

ContentDescription: Represent and describe the information and data from observations in different formats, including sketches and labelled maps or photographs
Elaboration: Interpreting geographical maps, concept maps, and other digital or visual displays to explore system connections, for example places their classmates are connected to, where some food comes from, or how Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples’ songlines connect places

ContentDescription: Represent and describe the information and data from observations in different formats, including sketches and labelled maps or photographs
Elaboration: Interpreting distance on maps using terms such as ‘distant’, ‘close’, ‘local’, ‘many hours in a bus/car/plane’ and ‘walking distance’ to decide on the accessibility of different features and places

ContentDescription: Draw conclusions and make proposals about places
Elaboration: Considering the general conclusions made from information collected, such as listing what makes a place significant and drawing conclusions about how people were, or are, connected to a local place and other places in the region and/or state or territory

ContentDescription: Draw conclusions and make proposals about places
Elaboration: Discussing information collected and using it to answer a geographical question

ContentDescription: Draw conclusions and make proposals about places
Elaboration: Describing features of a space or place that is important to them (e.g. a chicken coop, a play area, their bedroom, the reading corner or the beach) and suggesting or explaining what they could do to care for it

ContentDescription: Draw conclusions and make proposals about places
Elaboration: Exploring the location and features of places they belong to and what makes those places special

ContentDescription: Draw conclusions and make proposals about places
Elaboration: Identifying how knowledge of special places and natural systems in their local area contributes to behaviour, and ideas about how to care for these places and preserve their significance

ContentDescription: Draw conclusions and make proposals about places
Elaboration: Imagining how a local feature or place might change in the future and proposing actions they could take to improve a place or influence a positive future

ContentDescription: Draw conclusions and make proposals about places
Elaboration: Discussing how important their interconnections with places in Australia and the world are and discussing why this is so

ContentDescription: Develop narratives and share observations about places, using sources such as maps and photographs
Elaboration: Creating a display about a place that is special to them using maps, photographs, artefacts and/or drawings

ContentDescription: Develop narratives and share observations about places, using sources such as maps and photographs
Elaboration: Using appropriate terms to describe the direction and location of a place, such as ‘near’ and ‘far’, ‘above’ and ‘below’, or ‘beside’ and ‘opposite’

ContentDescription: Develop narratives and share observations about places, using sources such as maps and photographs
Elaboration: Sharing observations about a place, such as how access to and use of a place has changed over time, using sources such as maps and photographs

ContentDescription: Develop narratives and share observations about places, using sources such as maps and photographs
Elaboration: Preparing a narrative about how places can be managed

ContentDescription: Develop narratives and share observations about places, using sources such as maps and photographs
Elaboration: Designing an infographic about the different weather and seasons in their area
